The extent to which the deficiency or deficiencies are part of an ongoing pattern during the preceding 24 months;
The degree of risk to the health, life, or safety of the participants of the center that is caused by the deficiency or deficiencies;
The efforts made by, and the ability of, the center to correct the deficiency or deficiencies; and
A center's prior history of compliance.
If the Department determines that a deficiency or an ongoing pattern of deficiencies exists, the Department shall notify the center of the deficiency or deficiencies and may:
Impose a per day civil money penalty until sustained compliance has been achieved;
Permit the center the opportunity to correct the deficiencies by a specific date; or
Impose a per instance civil money penalty for each instance of violation.

If the Department permits a center the opportunity to correct the deficiencies by a specific date, and the center fails to comply with this requirement, the Department may impose a per day civil money penalty for each day of violation until correction of the deficiency or deficiencies has been verified and sustained compliance has been maintained.
If the Department proposes to impose a civil money penalty, the Secretary shall issue an order which shall state the:
Deficiency or deficiencies on which the order is based;
Amount of civil money penalties to be imposed; and
Manner in which the amount of civil money penalties imposed was calculated.
An order issued pursuant to this regulation shall be void unless issued within 60 days of the inspection or re-inspection at which the deficiency is identified.
A civil money penalty imposed under this chapter for potential for more than minimal harm deficiencies may not exceed:
$3,000 per instance; or
$300 per day for an ongoing pattern of deficiencies until the center is in compliance.
A civil money penalty imposed under this chapter for actual harm deficiencies may not exceed:
$5,000 per instance; or
$1,000 per day for an ongoing pattern of deficiencies until the center is in compliance.
A civil money penalty imposed under this chapter for a serious and immediate threat may not exceed:
$10,000 per instance; or
$3,000 per day for an ongoing pattern of deficiencies until the center is in compliance.
In setting the amount of a civil money penalty under this chapter, the Secretary shall consider the following factors:
The number, nature, and seriousness of the deficiencies;
The degree of risk to the health, life, or safety of the participants of the center caused by the deficiency or deficiencies;
The efforts made by the center to correct the deficiency or deficiencies;
Whether the amount of the proposed civil money penalty will jeopardize the financial ability of the center to continue operating as a center; and
Other factors as justice may require.
All civil money penalties collected under this chapter shall be paid into the general fund of the State.
A hearing on the appeal shall be held in accordance with the State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The Secretary shall have the burden of proof with respect to the imposition of the civil money penalties under this chapter.
Imposition of Penalty. The Secretary may impose a civil money penalty on a person who manages or operates an unlicensed center as follows:
A civil money penalty imposed on a person under this chapter may not exceed $10,000 for each offense; and
When a civil money penalty is imposed, the Secretary shall issue an order which includes the:
Deficiency or deficiencies on which the order is based;
Amount of civil money penalty to be imposed; and
Manner in which the amount of civil money penalty was calculated.
A person aggrieved by the action of the Secretary under this regulation may appeal the Secretary's action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with Regulation .53 of this chapter.
The Secretary may immediately suspend a license on finding that the public health, safety, or welfare imperatively requires emergency action.
The Department shall deliver a written notice to the center:
Informing it of the emergency suspension;
Giving the reasons for the action and the regulation or regulations with which the licensee has failed to comply that forms the basis for the emergency suspension; and
Notifying the center of its right to request a hearing and to be represented by counsel.
The filing of a hearing request does not stay the emergency action.
When a license is suspended by emergency action:
The center shall immediately return the license to the Department;
The center shall stop providing adult day care services immediately; and

The licensee shall notify the participants or representatives of the participants of the suspension and make every reasonable effort to assist them in making other arrangements for adult day care services.
A person aggrieved by the action of the Secretary under this regulation may appeal the Secretary's action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with Regulation .53 of this chapter.

Show Cause Hearing. In addition to the right to request a hearing in accordance with Regulation .53 of this chapter, a person aggrieved by the action of the Secretary under this regulation shall be provided with the opportunity for a hearing to show cause why the Department should lift the summary suspension.

If requested in writing, the show cause hearing shall be held promptly within a reasonable time after the effective date of the order of summary suspension. The time limit for filing an appeal with the Office of Administrative Hearings to obtain an evidentiary hearing shall be tolled by the filing of a request for a show cause hearing.
The show cause hearing shall be a non-evidentiary hearing to provide the parties with an opportunity for oral argument on the summary suspension.
The show cause hearing shall be conducted before the Secretary or a designee of the Secretary, who:
Shall determine procedural issues;
May impose reasonable time limits on each party's oral argument; and
Shall make rulings reasonably necessary to facilitate the effective and efficient operation of the show cause hearing.
At the conclusion of the show cause hearing, the Secretary or the Secretary's designee may:
Affirm the order of summary suspension;
Rescind the order of summary suspension;
Enter into a consent order; or
Enter into an interim order warranted by the circumstances of the case, including one providing for a stay of the summary suspension subject to certain conditions.

After the show cause hearing, if the Secretary or the Secretary's designee decides to continue the summary suspension, the person aggrieved by the decision may request an evidentiary hearing before the Office of Administrative Hearings in accordance with Regulation .53 of this chapter.

The Office of Administrative Hearings shall conduct a hearing as provided in Regulation .53 of this chapter and issue a proposed decision within the time frames set forth in COMAR 28.02.01. Exceptions may be filed by an aggrieved person pursuant to COMAR 10.01.03. The Secretary shall make a final decision pursuant to COMAR 10.01.03.
If the Secretary's final decision does not uphold the emergency suspension, the center may resume operation.

Denial or Revocation of License. The Secretary, for cause shown, shall notify the center of its decision to deny or revoke the center's license. The denial or revocation shall be stayed if a hearing is requested.
The Department shall notify the center in writing of the following:
The effective date of the denial or revocation;
The reason for the denial or revocation;
The regulations with which the licensee has failed to comply that form the basis for the denial or revocation;
That the center is entitled to a hearing if requested, and to be represented by counsel;
That the center shall stop providing services on the effective date of the denial or revocation if the center does not request a hearing;
That the denial or revocation shall be stayed if a hearing is requested; and
That the center is required to surrender its license to the Department if the denial or revocation is upheld.

The licensee shall notify the participants or participants' representatives of any final denial or revocation and make every reasonable effort to assist them in making other arrangements for adult day care.
A person aggrieved by the action of the Secretary under this regulation may appeal the Secretary's action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with Regulation .53 of this chapter.

A request for a hearing shall be filed with the Office of Administrative Hearings, with a copy to the Office of Health Care Quality of the Department, not later than 30 days after receipt of notice of the Secretary's action. The request shall include a copy of the Secretary's action.
A hearing requested under this chapter shall be conducted in accordance with:
State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland;
COMAR 28.02.01; and
The burden of proof is as provided in COMAR 10.01.03.28.
Unless otherwise stated in this chapter, the Office of Administrative Hearings shall issue a proposed decision within the time frames set forth in COMAR 28.02.01.
The aggrieved person may file exceptions as provided in COMAR 10.01.03.35.
A final decision by the Secretary shall be issued in accordance with COMAR 10.01.03.35.
